#Documentations for Mobile RSS Reader
= Introduction =

<div title="Summary">
<a name="summary"><h2>Summary</h2></a>
<p>
The free RSS feed reader/agregator is a cell phone (mobile) J2ME MIDP  application that
is able to read most RSS/Atom servers/feed versions. 
RSS is a lightweight XML format
designed for sharing headlines and other content like blogs and news.   
Data
is stored on the device and updated on request.  This uses the internet which
service providers charge extra for, so you would best get an unlimited data
from your service provider.  
This is licensed under GPL.  The program can be built and run using Free and
Open Software (FOS).  It can be run on Sun's J2ME as well.
Source code originally authored by Tommi Laukkanen is at
<a href="http://code.google.com/p/mobile-rss-reader/"> http://code.google.com/p/mobile-rss-reader/</a>
Modified GPL software from other projects are also used.
</div>
</p>

<div title="Which program to choose">
<a name="#which_program"><h2>
<!--wiki == wiki-->  Which program to choose<!--wiki == wiki-->  
</h2></a>
<p>
If you want to start quickly, you can choose the program that should work
for most phones, midp20_RSSReader.jar.  
This allows you to have the device
browser go to the link if requested.  All but one of the versions of the
program allow this.
Otherwise, read what follows.
Java ME (J2ME) has a flaw in that many features are optional.  The problem
occurs in that if a program uses an feature that is not present
on the phone, then trying to run that program may not give an error, but
the program will not run as it requires an feature not present on the phone.
This can be frustrating for a user as it will appear that the program does
not work when in fact is the phone that is not giving a proper error message.
For example, say a program has 2 versions.  One which can read the phone's
memory and one that cannot.  The ability to read the phone's memory is called
JSR-75.  If you run a program with JSR-75 on a phone that does not have that
feature, it may not come up and may not give an error message.  So, in this
case one needs to pick the phone version that does not read from phone memory.
</p>
<p>
So, it is important to see which features the phone has.  The features that
are important to know are CLDC-1.0, CLDC-1.1, MIDP-1.0 or MIDP-2.0, and JSR-75.  To find
the features go to 
<a href="http://www.mobref.com/device/">http://www.mobref.com/device</a>.
Find your phone and go to it's web page.  
Look for CLDC version.  It may
have 1 or 2 numbers 1.0 and/or 1.1.  Use the higher number this gives
CLDC-1.1.  
If this is the CLDC version, use a program which has cldc11
(e.g. midp20_cldc11_RSSReader.jar)
If CLDC version 1.0, use program without cldc11  (e.g. midp20_RSSReader.jar).
Look for MIDP version.  It may
have 1 or 2 numbers 1.0 and/or 2.0.  Use the the higher number this gives
MIDP-2.0.
If this is the MIDP version, use a program which has midp20
(e.g. midp20_cldc11_RSSReader.jar)
If version 1.0, use program without midp10  (e.g. midp10_RSSReader.jar).
Look for the Specific JSR.  If it has JSR-75, choose the program with jsr75
(e.g. midp20_jsr75_RSSReader).  If it does not have JSR-75, choose the program
without jsr75 (e.g. midp20_RSSReader).
</p>
If your phone is not listed on the link above, you can run the
midp10_RSSReader.jar and go to settings.  
Near the bottom it will say
phone MIDP.  Take that number or numbers there and use it as above for MIDP
version.
After phone MIDP, it has phone CLDC.  Take that number or numbers there and
use it as above for CLDC version.  
After phone CLDC, it has phone jsr75.  If that has true, the phone has JSR-75.
Use it as above for JSR-75.  
<p>
</p>
</div>
<div title="Install">
<a name="#install"><h2>Install/copy Mobile RSS Reader to phone instructions</h2></a>
 
<p>
To install/copy RSSReader to the phone, you will need some communication  
method between your computer and your phone to be working (e-mail, cable, 
bluetooth, or infrared), and copy the midp10_RSSReader.jar, midp20_RSSReader.jar,
midp20_jsr75_RSSReader.jar file  
(that is in the <a href="http://code.google.com/p/mobile-rss-reader/downloads/list">zip file (this link)</a> ) from the  
computer to the phone. If you have an old phone (that uses MIDP  
1.0), copy midp10_RSSReader.jar. The detailed steps are different 
from one phone to other, so please read the manual of your phone  
and the help of your communication program. 
</p>
 
<p>
Alternatively, you can use your phone browser to download  
RSSReader directly from this web.
</p>
Just enter this url for MIDP-2.0 and CLDC-1.0 (see above): 
<a href="http://mobile-rss-reader.googlecode.com/files/midp20_RSSReader-1.11.jar">http://mobile-rss-reader.googlecode.com/files/midp20_RSSReader-1.11.jar</a>
</p>

<p>
Just enter this url for MIDP-2.0, CLDC-1.0 and JSR-75 (see above): 
<a href="http://mobile-rss-reader.googlecode.com/files/midp20_jsr75_RSSReader-1.11.jar">http://mobile-rss-reader.googlecode.com/files/midp20_jsr75_RSSReader-1.11.jar</a>
</p>
 
<p>
If your phone is old (has MIDP-1.0), use this url: 
<a href="http://mobile-rss-reader.googlecode.com/files/midp10_RSSReader-1.11.jar">http://mobile-rss-reader.googlecode.com/files/midp10_RSSReader-1.11.jar</a>
</p>
</div>

<a name="#detail_features">
<h2>
<!--wiki == wiki-->Detailed Features<!--wiki == wiki-->  
</h2>
</a>
<div title="Detailed Features">
<p>
<a name="#phone_memory"><h2>
<!--wiki === wiki-->Reading from phone memory<!--wiki === wiki-->  
</h2></a>
Feeds and imports of feeds can be done from phone memory with phones with
JSR-75.  You can find this out by looking at technical specs for your phone,
looking up your phone at this web site.
<a href="http://www.mobref.com/device/">http://www.mobref.com/device</a>.
Or you can run the program without JSR-75 (midp20_RSSReader...)
going to settings and looking for phone jsr75 and if true, you can use jsr75
version (midp20_jsr75_RSSReader...). 
It is important to check before trying to run the JSR-75 version as if phone
does not support JSR75 the JSR-75 program (midp20_jsr75_RSSReader... will
not work or run) but not harm the phone.
</p>

<a name="#importing"><h2>Importing Feeds</h2></a>
<p>
The import feature has filters.  This is because there are some OPML files
that have 1,500 (SIC) links or HTML files with lots of links.
This would cause the program to
run out of memory or to be unmanageble.
Say you only want the ones that are about Tech.
Use the name filter with 'Tech' in it to get just the ones with Tech.
Some sites have an HTML file (URL) with links to RSS.  You can use the
HTML Links format to import from this file.  This file will
likely have both links for RSS and other links.  Usually, the RSS
links have a pattern in them like rss or xml.  Put rss or xml in the
link filter to just import these.  
You will need to open the page with view source and see what
to use as the filter.
</p>
</div>

<div title="build_instructions">
<a name="#build_instructions"><h2>Build instructions</h2></a>
<h3>All builds</h3>
<p>
You need to install the software (needed for build only) 
<ul>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li><a href="http://ant.apache.org">ant</a></li>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li><a href="http://antenna.sourceforge.net">antenna</a>
  version 1.1.0-beta.  Some of the previous versions don't run on Linux or
  have //#elif bug.</li>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/ant-contrib/">ant-contrib</a></li>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li>Java VM either Sun's, JamVM, or GNU GIJ</li>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li>Either compiler below</li>
<ul>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li><a href="http://download.java.net/jdk6/binaries/">Either JDK 1.5</a></li>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li>ECJ Eclipse compiler at <a href="http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/">Eclipse downloads</a>
  then, go to a release &gt;= 3.2.  Under JDT Core Batch an ecj.jar (usually
  contains a version)</li>
</ul>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li>Either Wireless Toolkit (WTK) below</li>
<ul>
<!--wiki   * wiki--><li><a href="https://meapplicationdevelopers.dev.java.net/how_to_run.html">phone ME</a></li>
<!--wiki   * wiki--><li><a href="http://java.sun.com/products/sjwtoolkit/download-2_5.html">Sun Wireless Toolkit</a></li>
<!--wiki   * wiki--><li><a href="http://www.netbeans.org/features/javame/index.html">Netbeans Mobility</a></li>
</ul>
<!--wiki * wiki--><li><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/proguard/">proguard</a></li>
</ul>
</p>
<p>
To build using antenna, go to wtkbuild directory, copy the files ending in
.template to the file name without '.template'.
In wtk-build.properties, change antenna.home value to point to directory
of the antenna jar.  Set antenna.jar to the name of the antenna jar.
Change antcontrib.home to point to location of ant-contrib-1.0b3.jar.
In wtk-build.properties file for linux, change value wtk.home to
&quot;&lt;PHONEME_INSTALL_DIR&gt;/bin/linux_x86_fb_chameleon_mvm&quot;.
Comment out wtk.wme.home value for linux.
In wtk-build.properties file for windows, change value wtk.home to
&quot;&lt;PHONEME_INSTALL_DIR&gt;/bin/win32_x86_javacall_mv&quot;.
Set wtk.wme.home value to localtion of Tools subdirectory under Websphere
Micro Edition (WME) install directory.  If you do not have WME, comment 
out wtk.wme.home in wtk-build.properties.
out.  
The following is for linux and windows.
Copy files under i386 to bin with -rp.
Uncomment property wtk.midpapi with value &quot;${wtk.home}/classes&quot;.
</p>
<p>
To compile and build everything,<br/>
<!-- {{{ -->
<code>
<pre>
export ANT_HOME=(location of ant)
export JAVA_HOME=(one directory above location of java)
export JAVACMD=(location of java)
ant dist
</pre>
</code>
<!-- }}} -->
</p>
